title: Two white UConn students arrested for shouting racial slurs outside campus housing in viral video
text:
Two University of Connecticut students have been arrested after a video of them shouting racial slurs went viral and sparked campus protests.

Jarred Karal and Ryan Mucaj, both 21, were arrested by the UConn Police Department and charged with ridicule on account of creed, religion, color, denomination, nationality or race, a university spokeswoman said Monday night.

Video shows the men yelling out the n-word repeatedly on the night of October 11 outside the student housing apartments.

The video went viral, catching the attention of campus police and hundreds of students who gathered for a protest Monday calling for racial inclusion and action from top school officials.

The two men were arrested just hours after the protest.

Jarred Karal and Ryan Mucaj, both 21, were arrested by the UConn Police Department Monday

Video showed the men yelling out the n-word repeatedly on the night of October 11 outside the student housing apartments

The video shows Karal, Mucaj and another student walking through the Charter Oak Apartment complex playing 'a game in which they yelled vulgar words,' according to a police report.

Police determined a third student seen in the video did not participate and was not charged.

Both men were released on written promises to appear and are scheduled to appear October 30 in Superior Court.

During Monday's protest, students and the campus NAACP were heard chanting 'it's more than just a word' and 'our voices will be heard.'

Professors and students gave impassioned speeches responding to the video and also a second incident on campus this week where two members of the Delta Epsilon Psi fraternity called allegedly called a female student a racial slur at a party.

The university chapter of the NAACP demanded the school disband the fraternity, update the university's student code of conduct regarding hate speech, hire new black staff members and implement a new mandatory diversity course, according to the Hartford Courant.

'As representatives for students of color on this campus, we are on high alert,' the group wrote to administrators in a letter published in the student newspaper, The Daily Campus.

'If the university does not adequately address and handle these occurrences of racism appropriately, it will create a culture in which racism is tolerated and normalized.'

UConn President Thomas Katsouleas condemned the students' racist language in a statement Monday night, calling their actions 'deplorable' and addressed the crowd at Monday's protest (pictured)

The video went viral, catching the attention of campus police and hundreds of students who gathered for a protest Monday calling for action

UConn President Thomas Katsouleas condemned the students' racist language in a statement Monday night, calling their actions 'deplorable'.

'It is supportive of our core values to pursue accountability, through due process, for an egregious assault on our community that has caused considerable harm,' Katsouleas said in a statement.

Katsouleas was also at the protest Monday to address the crowd: 'I'm really here to listen and to learn from you,' he said. 'I'm also here to show you my support. My message to the world is that if you are not for equality and respect then I am not for you.'

'I'm grateful for the university's collective effort in responding to this incident, especially the hard work of the UConn Police Department, which has been investigating the case since it was reported.

'This, or any similar incident, is deplorable and antithetical to the values of our community and the university as a whole. It has no place on our campuses - or anywhere.'
description: Jarred Karal and Ryan Mucaj, both 21, were arrested by the UConn Police Department Monday and charged with ridicule on account of creed, religion, color, denomination.
